column1: Kelowna () is a city on Okanagan Lake in the Okanagan Valley in the southern interior of British Columbia
column2: Canada. It serves as the head office of the Regional District of the Central Okanagan. The name Kelowna derives from an Okanagan language word for "grizzly bear".Kelowna is the province's third-largest metropolitan area (after Vancouver and Victoria)
column4: and the largest in the Interior. It is the 22nd-largest city in Canada. The city proper encompasses 211.82 square kilometres (81.78 sq mi)

column11: across Okanagan Lake; Lake Country and Vernon to the north; Peachland to the southwest; and Summerland and Penticton to the south.

column3: became the first European to settle in Kelowna in 1859 at a place he named "l'Anse au Sable" (Bay of Sand) in reference to the sandy shoreline. Kelowna was officially incorporated on 4 May 1905.Kelowna celebrated its centennial in May 2005. The same year

column5: as part of a plan to alleviate traffic problems during summer tourist season. The new bridge was completed in 2008.Stubbs House is a historic house in Kelowna.

column1: Kelowna is classified as a humid continental climate or an inland oceanic climate per the Köppen climate classification system due to its coldest month having an average temperature slightly above −3.0 °C (26.6 °F) and below 0 °C (32 °F)
column4: sunny summers and cool
column5: cloudy winters
column6: and four seasons. The official climate station for Kelowna is at the Kelowna International Airport
column7: which is at a higher altitude than the city core
column8: with slightly higher precipitation and cooler nighttime temperatures. Kelowna has the second mildest winter of any non-coastal city in Canada
column9: after neighbouring Penticton. This is caused by the moderating effects of Okanagan Lake combined with mountains separating most of BC from the prairies; however Arctic air masses do occasionally penetrate the valley during winter
column10: usually for very short periods. The coldest recorded temperature in the city was −36.1 °C (−33.0 °F) recorded on 30 December 1968.

column1: Weather conditions during December and January are the cloudiest in Canada outside of Newfoundland due to persistent valley cloud. As Okanagan Lake hardly ever freezes
column2: warmer air rising from the lake climbs above colder atmospheric air
column3: creating a temperature inversion which can cause the valley to be socked in by cloud. This valley cloud has a low ceiling
column4: however
column5: and often bright sunshine can be experienced by driving only 20 minutes or so up into the nearby mountains
column6: above the cloud. Summers in Kelowna are hot (sometimes extremely hot) and sunny
column7: with daytime temperatures often exceeding 32 °C (90 °F). The hottest recorded temperature at the airport was 39.5 °C (103.1 °F) on 24 July 1994
column8: and the highest temperature ever recorded in the city was 41.0 °C (105.8 °F) on 4 August 1998
column9: near but not at the airport. Not  unusually
column12: and even June and September on occasion
column13: where temperatures above 30 °C (86 °F) persist for weeks. During summer
column15: dry air allows night-time temperatures to fall rapidly. The city averages about 380 mm (15 in) of precipitation per year
column16: with about 1/5 of the precipitation falling as snow
column17: the bulk in December and January; however
column18: June is the wettest month of the year.

column1: While some smaller communities such as Blue River and Golden get less wind
column2: Kelowna has the greatest percentage of "calm" wind observations for any major city in Canada (39% of the time). The four-year average wind measured at the airport has been less than 5 knots on average 10/12 months of the year between 2008 and 2011. As shown in the climate chart below
column3: Kelowna has an average high temperature that is above freezing every month of the year - an exceptionally rare phenomenon for an inland Canadian city. In fact
column4: average high temperatures in January surpass those of St. John's
column5: Newfoundland
column6: which experiences heavy moderation from the warm Atlantic current. Kelowna's average year-round high temperature of about 14.3 °C (57.7 °F) is also one of the highest in Canada - largely due to the rare combination of high summer temperatures typical of continental climates
column7: along with relatively mild winters - a very rare feature of a continental climate.

column1: Kelowna consists of ten sectors with multiple neighbourhoods within the sector boundaries.
Central City is a linear commercial sector along Harvey Avenue
column2: from downtown to Highway 33. Major commercial developments include the Capri Centre mall
column4: and the Orchard Park Shopping Centre. Commercial activity is particularly concentrated along or near Highway 97 (Harvey).

column1: Dilworth Mountain is a relatively low
column2: isolated mountain of just over 2000 feet
column3: near the city's geographic center. Adjoining Knox Mountain to the west
column4: it is part of the eastern heights that form Glenmore Valley

column6: Dilworth has gone from relative isolation and wilderness to hosting hundreds of homes
column7: many of which are considered fairly high-end.

column1: Kelowna had a historic Chinatown in the area between Harvey Avenue and Leon Avenue
column2: east of Abbott and west of Highway 97/Harvey Avenue. Historically most residents of this Chinatown were males. In 1909 15% of Kelowna's population was ethnic Chinese. In 1911 the percentage was the same. That year Sun Yat-sen visited Kelowna for fundraising purposes. In 1978 the final remaining traditional Chinese business ceased operations. By 2010 less than 1% of Kelowna's population was ethnic Chinese. A section of the façade of the rebuilt "Chinese Store" that was in Chinatown is now housed at the Kelowna Museum.

column5: as part of the Government of Canada's Homelessness Partnering Strategy
column6: the Central Okanagan Foundation conducted a coordinated Point-in-Time (PiT) Count of Kelowna's homeless population.

column1: Kelowna faces severe suburbanization and urban sprawl promoted by the popularity of low-density car-oriented developments. As of 2007
column2: Kelowna has the highest car dependency rate in Canada and has the second highest per-capita road transportation carbon footprint in British Columbia. Despite having a metro population of about 200
column4: the greater Kelowna area is slightly bigger than that of Metro Vancouver. Road transportation accounts for more than 65% of total greenhouse gas emission in the city.
